questions.question: Which pigment is responsible for the brown colour of Phaeophyceae?
questions.explanation: Fucoxanthin is the predominant accessory pigment in brown algae (Phaeophyceae), which masks the green colour of chlorophyll and gives them their characteristic brown colour.

questions.question: The stored food in Rhodophyceae is:
questions.explanation: The reserve food in red algae (Rhodophyceae) is floridean starch, which is similar to amylopectin and glycogen in structure.

questions.question: Which of the following is a liverwort?
questions.explanation: Marchantia is a common liverwort (Hepaticopsida). Funaria, Sphagnum, and Polytrichum are all mosses (Bryopsida).

questions.question: In which group of plants is the sporophyte not free-living but attached to the photosynthetic gametophyte?
questions.explanation: In bryophytes, the sporophyte is not free-living but attached to the photosynthetic gametophyte and derives nourishment from it. The dominant phase is the gametophyte.

questions.question: The first vascular plants to appear on land were:
questions.explanation: Pteridophytes are the first terrestrial plants to possess vascular tissues (xylem and phloem). They are found in cool, damp, shady places though some may flourish well in sandy-soil conditions.

questions.question: Which of the following gymnosperms is a living fossil?
questions.explanation: Ginkgo biloba is called a living fossil because it is the only surviving species of a once widespread group of plants that existed millions of years ago.

questions.question: Double fertilization is a characteristic feature of:
questions.explanation: Double fertilization is unique to angiosperms. One male gamete fuses with the egg cell to form the zygote (syngamy) and the other fuses with the two polar nuclei to form the triploid primary endosperm nucleus (triple fusion).

questions.question: In Chlorophyceae, the cell wall is made up of:
questions.explanation: In green algae (Chlorophyceae), the cell wall has an inner layer of cellulose and an outer layer of pectose.

questions.question: The plant body of moss is differentiated into:
options: B) Stem-like and leaf-like structures only
D) Stem-like, leaf-like structures and multicellular rhizoids
questions.explanation: In mosses, the gametophyte consists of a central axis bearing spirally arranged leaf-like structures (phylloids), stem-like structures (cauloids), and multicellular rhizoids for anchorage.

questions.question: Heterospory, i.e., formation of two kinds of spores, is seen in:
questions.explanation: Selaginella and Salvinia are heterosporous pteridophytes, producing two kinds of spores: microspores and megaspores. The development of the zygote into young embryos within the female gametophyte is an important step towards seed habit.

questions.question: In gymnosperms, the ovules are:
options: D) Present in a closed carpel
A) Enclosed within the ovary wall
questions.explanation: In gymnosperms, the ovules are not enclosed by any ovary wall and remain exposed on the megasporophylls. The term gymnosperm itself means 'naked seeds'.

questions.question: Sphagnum is commonly known as:
questions.explanation: Sphagnum is commonly called peat moss. It is economically important as it provides peat, which is used as fuel and also in horticulture for its water-holding capacity.

questions.question: Agar is commercially obtained from:
questions.explanation: Agar is obtained from red algae (Rhodophyceae) such as Gelidium and Gracilaria. It is used commercially in the preparation of ice-creams, jellies, and also as a culture medium in laboratories.

questions.question: In the haplontic life cycle:
options: B) The gametophyte is the dominant, free-living phase
A) The sporophyte is the dominant phase
D) Neither sporophyte nor gametophyte is free-living
C) Both sporophyte and gametophyte are equally dominant
questions.explanation: In the haplontic life cycle, the dominant, free-living, photosynthetic phase is the gametophyte (haploid). The sporophytic generation is represented only by the one-celled zygote. Examples include Volvox, Spirogyra, and Chlamydomonas.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of plants belong to Chlorophyceae?
questions.explanation: Chlamydomonas and Spirogyra are green algae belonging to Chlorophyceae. Laminaria and Sargassum are Phaeophyceae, while Porphyra and Gracilaria are Rhodophyceae.

questions.question: The protonema stage is found in the life cycle of:
questions.explanation: Moss spores germinate to form a creeping, green, branched, filamentous stage called the protonema. It is the first stage in the development of the moss gametophyte.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of monocotyledons?
options: D) Two cotyledons in the seed
questions.explanation: Monocotyledons characteristically have trimerous flowers (floral parts in multiples of three), parallel venation, fibrous root system, and a single cotyledon in the seed.

questions.question: Archegonia are absent in:
questions.explanation: Archegonia are female sex organs found in bryophytes, pteridophytes, and gymnosperms. In angiosperms, the female gametophyte is reduced and does not produce archegonia.

questions.question: Algin is commercially obtained from:
questions.explanation: Algin is obtained from the cell walls of brown algae (Phaeophyceae). It is used as a hydrocolloid in the food and textile industries.

questions.question: The male sex organ of bryophytes is called:
questions.explanation: The male sex organ in bryophytes is called the antheridium. It produces biflagellate antherozoids (male gametes). The female sex organ is the archegonium, which produces a single egg.

questions.question: Pteridophytes are used for medicinal purposes and as soil binders. Which of the following is also used as an ornamental plant?
questions.explanation: Adiantum (maidenhair fern) is widely grown as an ornamental plant. Selaginella and Salvinia are heterosporous, and Azolla is used as a biofertilizer.

questions.question: In which of the following the sporophytic generation is dominant?
questions.explanation: In pteridophytes like Dryopteris (a fern), the sporophyte is the dominant, independent, photosynthetic phase. The gametophyte (prothallus) is small and short-lived.

questions.question: Which class of algae has predominantly unicellular members?
questions.explanation: Chlorophyceae members can be unicellular (Chlamydomonas), colonial (Volvox), or filamentous (Ulothrix, Spirogyra). They have the greatest diversity in body forms. Phaeophyceae members are predominantly marine and mostly multicellular.

questions.question: The gametophyte in pteridophytes is called:
questions.explanation: In pteridophytes, spores germinate to give rise to an inconspicuous, small but multicellular, free-living, mostly photosynthetic thalloid gametophyte called the prothallus.

questions.question: The cell wall of Phaeophyceae is composed of:
questions.explanation: The cell wall of brown algae (Phaeophyceae) is composed of cellulose and algin (alginic acid). Algin is a commercially important product obtained from brown algae.

questions.question: Bryophytes are also called amphibians of the plant kingdom because:
options: C) They need water for fertilization and can live in moist habitats
D) They have both aquatic and terrestrial sporophytes
A) They can live in water only
B) They can live on land only
questions.explanation: Bryophytes are called amphibians of the plant kingdom because they can live in soil but need water for sexual reproduction. The antherozoids (male gametes) are flagellated and require water to reach the archegonium.

questions.question: Coralloid roots in Cycas are associated with:
questions.explanation: Cycas has specialized coralloid roots that contain nitrogen-fixing cyanobacteria (Nostoc or Anabaena) in a symbiotic association.

questions.question: The haplo-diplontic life cycle is characteristic of:
questions.explanation: Bryophytes and pteridophytes exhibit haplo-diplontic life cycles where both the gametophytic (haploid) and sporophytic (diploid) phases are multicellular. In bryophytes the gametophyte is dominant, while in pteridophytes the sporophyte is dominant.

questions.question: The tallest living gymnosperm is:
questions.explanation: Sequoia sempervirens (coast redwood) is the tallest living gymnosperm and one of the tallest trees in the world, reaching heights of over 100 meters.

questions.question: Chlorophyll a, b, and carotenoids are present in:
questions.explanation: Chlorophyceae (green algae) contain chlorophyll a, chlorophyll b, and carotenoids. Phaeophyceae has chlorophyll a, c, and fucoxanthin. Rhodophyceae has chlorophyll a, d, and phycoerythrin.

questions.question: Elaters are present in:
questions.explanation: Elaters are hygroscopic structures found in the sporangium of liverworts like Marchantia. They help in the dispersal of spores by their coiling and uncoiling movements.

questions.question: The stored food in Phaeophyceae is:
questions.explanation: In brown algae (Phaeophyceae), the food is stored as mannitol and laminarin (a complex carbohydrate).

questions.question: Isogamous reproduction with non-flagellated gametes is found in:
questions.explanation: Spirogyra shows isogamous reproduction with non-flagellated gametes. The sexual reproduction occurs by conjugation where similar-looking, non-motile gametes fuse.

questions.question: Seeds are not formed in:
questions.explanation: Pteridophytes do not form seeds. They reproduce through spores. Seeds are formed in gymnosperms and angiosperms (spermatophytes). Though some pteridophytes show heterospory (a precursor to seed habit), they do not form true seeds.

questions.question: The largest ovules, largest male gametes, and largest female cones are found in:
questions.explanation: Cycas has the largest ovules and largest sperms (male gametes) among all living plants. Its female cones are also the largest in the plant kingdom.

questions.question: The diplontic life cycle is found in:
questions.explanation: Fucus shows a diplontic life cycle where the diploid sporophyte is the dominant, photosynthetic, independent phase. All seed-bearing plants (gymnosperms and angiosperms) also show diplontic life cycles.

questions.question: Which of the following pteridophytes is used as a biofertilizer in rice fields?
questions.explanation: Azolla is an aquatic fern that harbours nitrogen-fixing cyanobacteria (Anabaena azollae) in its leaf cavities and is used as a biofertilizer, particularly in rice paddy fields.

questions.question: Dicotyledons differ from monocotyledons in having:
questions.explanation: Dicotyledons typically show reticulate (net-like) venation in their leaves, as opposed to parallel venation in monocotyledons. They also have a tap root system, tetramerous or pentamerous flowers, and two cotyledons.

questions.question: Which of the following has siphonogamy (pollination through pollen tube)?
questions.explanation: Siphonogamy, the delivery of male gametes through a pollen tube, is found in gymnosperms and angiosperms. Bryophytes and pteridophytes require water for transfer of male gametes.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Bryophytes are called amphibians of the plant kingdom.
Reason (R): They need water for the transfer of male gametes and can survive on land in moist habitats.
options: C) A is true but R is false
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Bryophytes are called amphibians because they live on land but require water for sexual reproduction. The flagellated antherozoids need a film of water to swim and reach the archegonium for fertilization.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Gymnosperms produce naked seeds.
Reason (R): In gymnosperms, the ovules are enclosed within the ovary wall.
options: B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
C) A is true but R is false
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Gymnosperms produce naked seeds because their ovules are not enclosed within an ovary wall. The ovules are borne exposed on the megasporophylls. Hence, the assertion is true but the reason is false.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Selaginella and Salvinia are called heterosporous pteridophytes.
Reason (R): They produce two types of spores: microspores and megaspores.
options: B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Selaginella and Salvinia are heterosporous pteridophytes because they produce two kinds of spores: small microspores (which develop into male gametophytes) and larger megaspores (which develop into female gametophytes).

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Algae are chlorophyll-bearing, autotrophic thallophytes.
Reason (R): The plant body of algae is always filamentous.
options: D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: Algae are indeed chlorophyll-bearing, simple, thalloid, autotrophic, and largely aquatic organisms. However, the plant body of algae is not always filamentous; it can also be unicellular (Chlamydomonas), colonial (Volvox), or massive multicellular (kelps).

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Pteridophytes are used for medicinal purposes and as soil binders.
Reason (R): Pteridophytes have true roots, stems, and leaves with well-differentiated vascular tissues.
options: C) A is true but R is false
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Both statements are true. Pteridophytes do have economic importance as medicinal plants and soil binders. They also have true roots, stems, and leaves with vascular tissues. However, the reason does not explain why they are used medicinally or as soil binders.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): In mosses, the predominant stage is the gametophyte.
Reason (R): The gametophyte of mosses is more elaborate and has a protonema and leafy stage.
options: D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: In mosses, the gametophyte is the dominant phase. It has two stages: the protonema (a creeping, green, branched filamentous stage) and the leafy stage (an upright structure with spirally arranged leaves). The sporophyte is dependent on the gametophyte.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Red algae can grow at greater depths in the ocean than green or brown algae.
Reason (R): Red algae have phycoerythrin that can absorb blue-green wavelengths of light that penetrate deeper into water.
options: D) A is false but R is true
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Red algae can grow at greater depths because their accessory pigment phycoerythrin absorbs blue-green light, which penetrates deeper into ocean water. This gives them a competitive advantage at greater depths.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Double fertilization is unique to angiosperms.
Reason (R): In angiosperms, one male gamete fuses with the egg and the other fuses with the secondary nucleus.
options: D) A is false but R is true
C) A is true but R is false
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Double fertilization is indeed unique to angiosperms. One male gamete fuses with the egg cell (syngamy) to form the zygote, and the second male gamete fuses with the two polar nuclei (or secondary nucleus) to form the triploid primary endosperm nucleus (triple fusion).

questions.question:
Assertion (A): The zygote in Chlamydomonas undergoes meiosis to produce haploid spores.
Reason (R): Chlamydomonas shows a haplontic life cycle where the diploid phase is represented only by the zygote.
options: D) A is false but R is true
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: In Chlamydomonas, the life cycle is haplontic. The dominant phase is haploid. The only diploid structure is the zygote, which undergoes meiosis to produce haploid spores that grow into haploid organisms.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Polysiphonia shows a haplo-diplontic life cycle.
Reason (R): In Polysiphonia, both gametophytic and sporophytic phases are multicellular and free-living.
options: A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: Polysiphonia (a red alga) exhibits a haplo-diplontic life cycle. Both the haploid gametophyte and diploid sporophyte are multicellular and independent, alternating in the life cycle.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Gymnosperms do not bear fruits.
Reason (R): The ovules of gymnosperms are not enclosed inside an ovary, so no true fruit is formed after fertilization.
options: A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: Gymnosperms do not form fruits because fruits develop from ovaries, and gymnosperms lack an ovary wall surrounding the ovules. The seeds remain naked on the megasporophylls.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Ectocarpus shows isogamous as well as oogamous type of reproduction.
Reason (R): In Ectocarpus, sexual reproduction may involve fusion of two similar gametes or fusion of a large non-motile female gamete with a small motile male gamete.
options: D) Both A and R are false
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Ectocarpus shows isogamous type of sexual reproduction, not oogamous. Oogamous reproduction in Phaeophyceae is seen in Fucus. Hence, both the assertion and reason are false.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): The sporophyte in Funaria is differentiated into foot, seta, and capsule.
Reason (R): The sporophyte in Funaria is completely dependent on the gametophyte for nutrition.
options: D) A is false but R is true
C) A is true but R is false
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Both statements are true. The sporophyte of Funaria (a moss) is differentiated into foot, seta, and capsule. It is also dependent on the gametophyte. However, the differentiation into foot, seta, and capsule is not because of its dependence on the gametophyte; these are structural features of the sporophyte.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Angiosperms show the most advanced form of reproduction among plants.
Reason (R): Angiosperms exhibit double fertilization and produce seeds enclosed within fruits.
options: B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Angiosperms represent the most advanced group of plants with highly evolved reproductive features: double fertilization, formation of endosperm, seeds enclosed within fruits (providing protection and aiding dispersal), and highly reduced gametophytes.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about Chlorophyceae:
(i) They are commonly called green algae.
(ii) They contain chlorophyll a and b.
(iii) The stored food is starch.
(iv) The cell wall is made of cellulose and algin.
Which of the above statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Chlorophyceae are green algae containing chlorophyll a and b, with starch as stored food. Their cell wall is composed of cellulose and pectose, not cellulose and algin (algin is found in Phaeophyceae).

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about gymnosperms is INCORRECT?
(i) They have naked seeds.
(ii) They are heterosporous.
(iii) They show double fertilization.
(iv) The male and female gametophytes are free-living.
questions.explanation: Gymnosperms do NOT show double fertilization (unique to angiosperms) and their gametophytes are NOT free-living. The male gametophyte is the pollen grain, and the female gametophyte develops within the ovule.

questions.question:
Read the following statements and select the correct option:
Statement 1: Liverworts grow in moist, shady habitats.
Statement 2: The plant body of liverworts is thalloid.
Statement 3: Asexual reproduction in liverworts takes place by fragmentation or by gemmae.
options: C) All three statements are correct
questions.explanation: All three statements are correct as per NCERT. Liverworts grow in moist, shady habitats. Their plant body is thalloid (e.g., Marchantia). Asexual reproduction occurs by fragmentation or by specialised structures called gemmae (found in gemma cups).

questions.question:
How many of the following statements are correct?
(i) Algae are found in moist stones, soils, and wood.
(ii) Some algae occur in association with fungi (lichen) and animals (on sloth bear).
(iii) All algae are microscopic.
(iv) Algae reproduce by vegetative, asexual, and sexual methods.
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iv) are correct. Statement (iii) is incorrect because not all algae are microscopic; kelps (brown algae) can grow to enormous sizes. Algae are found in diverse habitats, can form lichens with fungi, and reproduce by all three methods.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about Phaeophyceae is/are correct?
(i) They are predominantly marine.
(ii) They possess chlorophyll a, c, and fucoxanthin.
(iii) Food is stored as mannitol and laminarin.
(iv) Their zoospores are laterally biflagellate with one smooth and one tinsel flagellum.
questions.explanation: All four statements are correct about Phaeophyceae (brown algae). They are predominantly marine, contain chlorophyll a, c and fucoxanthin, store food as mannitol and laminarin, and have laterally biflagellate zoospores with unequal flagella (one tinsel and one whiplash).

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about angiosperms:
(i) They bear seeds enclosed within fruits.
(ii) They show double fertilization.
(iii) Male sex organs are present in the stamen.
(iv) All angiosperms are woody plants.
How many of the above statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are correct. Statement (iv) is incorrect as angiosperms include both herbaceous and woody plants. Angiosperms bear seeds within fruits, exhibit double fertilization, and have stamens as male reproductive organs.

questions.question:
Read the following statements:
Statement I: Pteridophytes have well-differentiated vascular tissues.
Statement II: The sporophyte is the dominant phase in pteridophytes.
Statement III: The gametophyte (prothallus) of pteridophytes requires water for fertilization.
Select the correct option:
options: B) Only II and III are correct
A) Only I and II are correct
questions.explanation: All three statements are correct. Pteridophytes have well-differentiated xylem and phloem, the sporophyte is the dominant and independent phase, and the gametophyte (prothallus) requires water for the movement of flagellated antherozoids to the archegonium.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements is INCORRECT about the life cycle patterns in plants?
(i) In haplontic life cycle, the sporophyte is dominant.
(ii) In diplontic life cycle, the gametophyte is dominant.
(iii) In haplo-diplontic life cycle, both phases are multicellular.
(iv) All seed-bearing plants show diplontic life cycle.
questions.explanation: Statements (i) and (ii) are incorrect. In haplontic life cycle, the gametophyte (not sporophyte) is dominant. In diplontic life cycle, the sporophyte (not gametophyte) is dominant. Statements (iii) and (iv) are correct.

questions.question:
Which of the following is correct about Rhodophyceae?
(i) They are commonly called red algae.
(ii) They contain chlorophyll a, d, and phycoerythrin.
(iii) They store food as floridean starch.
(iv) They are predominantly freshwater forms.
questions.explanation: Rhodophyceae are red algae with chlorophyll a, d, and phycoerythrin, storing food as floridean starch. Statement (iv) is incorrect because the majority of red algae are marine, found in warmer areas and at greater depths of the ocean.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about pteridophyte classification:
(i) Psilopsida includes Psilotum.
(ii) Lycopsida includes Selaginella.
(iii) Sphenopsida includes Equisetum.
(iv) Pteropsida includes Dryopteris and Adiantum.
Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: All four statements are correct. Pteridophytes are classified into four classes: Psilopsida (e.g., Psilotum), Lycopsida (e.g., Selaginella, Lycopodium), Sphenopsida (e.g., Equisetum), and Pteropsida (e.g., Dryopteris, Pteris, Adiantum).

questions.question:
Read the following statements about mosses:
Statement A: The predominant stage of the moss life cycle is the sporophyte.
Statement B: Mosses have rhizoids that are multicellular and branched.
Statement C: The protonema develops from a moss spore.
Which of the above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Statement A is incorrect; in mosses, the dominant stage is the gametophyte, not the sporophyte. Statement B is correct; mosses have multicellular, branched rhizoids (unlike liverworts that have unicellular rhizoids). Statement C is correct; the protonema is the first stage developed from a germinating moss spore.

questions.question:
How many of the following features are shared by bryophytes and pteridophytes?
(i) Presence of vascular tissue
(ii) Requirement of water for fertilization
(iii) Production of spores
(iv) Multicellular sporangia with jacket layer
(v) Alternation of generations
questions.explanation: Features shared by both bryophytes and pteridophytes are: (ii) water requirement for fertilization, (iii) production of spores, and (v) alternation of generations. Vascular tissue (i) is absent in bryophytes. Both have multicellular sporangia but this differs in structure between the two groups.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements:
(i) Chara has a plant body that is branched and covered with calcium carbonate.
(ii) Volvox is a colonial green alga.
(iii) Ulothrix is a filamentous green alga.
(iv) Laminaria is a green alga.
Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are correct. Chara is encrusted with calcium carbonate, Volvox is a colonial green alga, and Ulothrix is filamentous. Statement (iv) is incorrect; Laminaria is a brown alga (Phaeophyceae), not green.

questions.question:
Select the INCORRECT statement about gymnosperms:
(i) Roots in some gymnosperms have fungal association (mycorrhiza).
(ii) In Cycas, coralloid roots contain Nostoc.
(iii) Pinus leaves are needle-like.
(iv) All gymnosperms are deciduous trees.
questions.explanation: Statement (iv) is incorrect. Not all gymnosperms are deciduous; most gymnosperms (like Pinus, Cedrus) are evergreen. Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are all correct as per NCERT.

questions.question:
Match the following algae with their classes:
Column I: (a) Spirogyra (b) Laminaria (c) Polysiphonia (d) Chlamydomonas
Column II: (i) Rhodophyceae (ii) Chlorophyceae (iii) Phaeophyceae
questions.explanation: Spirogyra and Chlamydomonas are green algae (Chlorophyceae), Laminaria is a brown alga (Phaeophyceae), and Polysiphonia is a red alga (Rhodophyceae).

questions.question:
Match the plant groups with their stored food:
Column I: (a) Chlorophyceae (b) Phaeophyceae (c) Rhodophyceae
Column II: (i) Floridean starch (ii) Starch (iii) Mannitol and laminarin
questions.explanation: Chlorophyceae stores starch, Phaeophyceae stores mannitol and laminarin, and Rhodophyceae stores floridean starch.

questions.question:
Match the plant groups with the dominant phase in their life cycle:
Column I: (a) Mosses (b) Ferns (c) Angiosperms (d) Volvox
Column II: (i) Sporophyte dominant (ii) Gametophyte dominant (iii) Diplontic (iv) Haplontic
questions.explanation: In mosses, the gametophyte is dominant. In ferns, the sporophyte is dominant. Angiosperms show a diplontic life cycle with dominant sporophyte. Volvox shows a haplontic life cycle with dominant gametophyte.

questions.question:
Match the following plant groups with their characteristics:
Column I: (a) Bryophytes (b) Pteridophytes (c) Gymnosperms (d) Angiosperms
Column II: (i) Naked seeds (ii) Enclosed seeds (iii) No vascular tissue (iv) First vascular plants
questions.explanation: Bryophytes lack vascular tissue. Pteridophytes were the first vascular plants. Gymnosperms bear naked seeds. Angiosperms bear seeds enclosed within fruits.

questions.question:
Match the following algal genera with their body form:
Column I: (a) Chlamydomonas (b) Volvox (c) Ulothrix (d) Chara
Column II: (i) Colonial (ii) Unicellular (iii) Branched multicellular (iv) Filamentous
questions.explanation: Chlamydomonas is unicellular, Volvox is colonial, Ulothrix is filamentous, and Chara is a branched multicellular green alga.

questions.question:
Match the pteridophyte classes with their examples:
Column I: (a) Psilopsida (b) Lycopsida (c) Sphenopsida (d) Pteropsida
Column II: (i) Equisetum (ii) Dryopteris (iii) Psilotum (iv) Selaginella
questions.explanation: Psilopsida includes Psilotum, Lycopsida includes Selaginella and Lycopodium, Sphenopsida includes Equisetum (horsetails), and Pteropsida includes Dryopteris, Pteris, and Adiantum (true ferns).

questions.question:
Match the following algal products with their sources:
Column I: (a) Agar (b) Algin (c) Carrageenan (d) Chlorella (protein source)
Column II: (i) Brown algae (ii) Green algae (iii) Red algae (Gelidium) (iv) Red algae (Chondrus)
questions.explanation: Agar is obtained from red algae Gelidium and Gracilaria. Algin is obtained from brown algae. Carrageenan comes from red algae like Chondrus. Chlorella is a unicellular green alga used as a food supplement.

questions.question:
Match the types of sexual reproduction with the algal genera:
Column I: (a) Isogamy (flagellated) (b) Isogamy (non-flagellated) (c) Anisogamy (d) Oogamy
Column II: (i) Fucus (ii) Spirogyra (iii) Eudorina (iv) Chlamydomonas
questions.explanation: Chlamydomonas shows isogamy with flagellated gametes. Spirogyra shows isogamy with non-flagellated gametes. Eudorina shows anisogamy. Fucus shows oogamy (large non-motile egg and small motile sperm).

questions.question:
Match the following features with the correct plant group:
Column I: (a) Elaters for spore dispersal (b) Protonema stage (c) Prothallus (d) Pollen tube
Column II: (i) Pteridophytes (ii) Gymnosperms (iii) Liverworts (iv) Mosses
questions.explanation: Elaters are found in liverworts (like Marchantia) for spore dispersal. Protonema is the first stage in moss development. Prothallus is the gametophyte of pteridophytes. Pollen tube is found in gymnosperms and angiosperms.

questions.question:
Match the following algae with their pigments:
Column I: (a) Chlorophyceae (b) Phaeophyceae (c) Rhodophyceae
Column II: (i) Chlorophyll a, d, phycoerythrin (ii) Chlorophyll a, b, carotenoids (iii) Chlorophyll a, c, fucoxanthin
questions.explanation: Chlorophyceae contains chlorophyll a, b and carotenoids. Phaeophyceae contains chlorophyll a, c and fucoxanthin. Rhodophyceae contains chlorophyll a, d and phycoerythrin.

questions.question:
Match the gymnosperm genera with their features:
Column I: (a) Cycas (b) Pinus (c) Ginkgo (d) Sequoia
Column II: (i) Living fossil (ii) Tallest gymnosperm (iii) Coralloid roots with Nostoc (iv) Needle-like leaves in fascicles
questions.explanation: Cycas has coralloid roots with Nostoc. Pinus has needle-like leaves arranged in fascicles. Ginkgo biloba is a living fossil. Sequoia is the tallest living gymnosperm.

questions.question:
Match the life cycles with their examples:
Column I: (a) Haplontic (b) Diplontic (c) Haplo-diplontic (algae) (d) Haplo-diplontic (land plant)
Column II: (i) Fucus (ii) Polysiphonia (iii) Funaria (iv) Volvox
questions.explanation: Volvox shows haplontic life cycle. Fucus shows diplontic life cycle. Polysiphonia (red alga) shows haplo-diplontic life cycle among algae. Funaria (moss) shows haplo-diplontic life cycle among land plants.

questions.question:
Match the following:
Column I: (a) Gemma cups (b) Sphagnum (c) Anthoceros (d) Funaria
Column II: (i) Peat moss (ii) Hornwort (iii) Marchantia (iv) Common moss
questions.explanation: Gemma cups are found in Marchantia (liverwort) for asexual reproduction. Sphagnum is peat moss. Anthoceros is a hornwort. Funaria is a common moss (also called cord moss).

questions.question:
Match the cell wall composition with the algal classes:
Column I: (a) Cellulose and pectose (b) Cellulose and algin (c) Cellulose, pectin, and polysulphate esters
Column II: (i) Phaeophyceae (ii) Chlorophyceae (iii) Rhodophyceae
questions.explanation: Chlorophyceae has cell wall of cellulose and pectose. Phaeophyceae has cellulose and algin. Rhodophyceae has cellulose, pectin, and polysulphate esters.

questions.question:
How many of the following are examples of Chlorophyceae?
Chlamydomonas, Volvox, Ulothrix, Spirogyra, Ectocarpus, Laminaria, Gelidium, Chara
questions.explanation: Chlamydomonas, Volvox, Ulothrix, Spirogyra, and Chara are all members of Chlorophyceae (green algae). Ectocarpus and Laminaria belong to Phaeophyceae, and Gelidium belongs to Rhodophyceae.

questions.question:
How many of the following plant groups require water for fertilization?
Bryophytes, Pteridophytes, Gymnosperms, Angiosperms, Chlorophyceae
questions.explanation: Bryophytes, Pteridophytes, and Chlorophyceae (being aquatic or requiring water medium for gamete transfer) require water for fertilization. Gymnosperms and Angiosperms use pollen tubes for fertilization and do not need external water.

questions.question:
How many of the following are heterosporous pteridophytes?
Selaginella, Salvinia, Dryopteris, Adiantum, Equisetum, Lycopodium, Marsilea
questions.explanation: Selaginella, Salvinia, and Marsilea are heterosporous pteridophytes that produce both microspores and megaspores. Dryopteris, Adiantum, Equisetum, and Lycopodium are homosporous.

questions.question:
Count the number of correct statements:
(i) Mosses have unicellular rhizoids.
(ii) Liverworts have unicellular rhizoids.
(iii) In mosses, the plant body is differentiated into stem and leaves.
(iv) In liverworts, the plant body is thalloid.
(v) Sphagnum provides peat.
questions.explanation: Statements (ii), (iii), (iv), and (v) are correct. Statement (i) is incorrect; mosses have multicellular rhizoids, while liverworts have unicellular rhizoids. Mosses have stem-like and leaf-like structures. Liverworts are thalloid. Sphagnum is peat moss.

questions.question:
How many of the following are features of angiosperms?
(i) Double fertilization (ii) Presence of vessel elements (iii) Enclosed ovules (iv) Flowers with four whorls (v) Naked seeds (vi) Reduced gametophyte
questions.explanation: Features (i) double fertilization, (ii) vessel elements, (iii) enclosed ovules, (iv) flowers with four whorls, and (vi) reduced gametophyte are all features of angiosperms. Feature (v) naked seeds is a feature of gymnosperms, not angiosperms.

questions.question:
How many of the following genera belong to Phaeophyceae?
Ectocarpus, Dictyota, Laminaria, Sargassum, Fucus, Polysiphonia, Gelidium, Gracilaria
questions.explanation: Ectocarpus, Dictyota, Laminaria, Sargassum, and Fucus belong to Phaeophyceae (brown algae). Polysiphonia, Gelidium, and Gracilaria belong to Rhodophyceae (red algae).

questions.question:
How many of the following plant groups have archegonia?
(i) Algae (ii) Bryophytes (iii) Pteridophytes (iv) Gymnosperms (v) Angiosperms
questions.explanation: Archegonia (female sex organs) are found in Bryophytes, Pteridophytes, and Gymnosperms. Algae have simpler reproductive structures, and angiosperms have a highly reduced female gametophyte (embryo sac) without archegonia.

questions.question:
How many of the following show haplontic life cycle?
Chlamydomonas, Volvox, Spirogyra, Fucus, Polysiphonia, Ectocarpus
questions.explanation: Chlamydomonas, Volvox, and Spirogyra show haplontic life cycle where the dominant phase is haploid gametophyte and the only diploid structure is the zygote. Fucus shows diplontic, while Polysiphonia and Ectocarpus show haplo-diplontic life cycles.

questions.question: Arrange the following plant groups in order of their evolutionary complexity (simplest to most complex):
options: A) Algae  Bryophytes  Pteridophytes  Gymnosperms  Angiosperms
C) Algae  Pteridophytes  Bryophytes  Gymnosperms  Angiosperms
D) Pteridophytes  Algae  Bryophytes  Angiosperms  Gymnosperms
B) Bryophytes  Algae  Pteridophytes  Angiosperms  Gymnosperms
questions.explanation: The correct evolutionary sequence from simplest to most complex is: Algae (thallophytes)  Bryophytes (amphibians)  Pteridophytes (first vascular)  Gymnosperms (naked seeds)  Angiosperms (enclosed seeds, most advanced).

questions.question:
Arrange the following stages in the life cycle of a moss in correct sequence:
(i) Protonema (ii) Spore germination (iii) Leafy gametophyte (iv) Sporophyte (v) Antherozoids reach archegonium
options: C) ii  iii  i  v  iv
D) iii  ii  i  iv  v
A) ii  i  iii  v  iv
B) i  ii  iii  iv  v
questions.explanation: The correct sequence is: Spore germination  Protonema stage  Leafy gametophyte develops  Antherozoids reach archegonium (fertilization)  Sporophyte develops on the gametophyte.

questions.question:
Arrange the following events of double fertilization in angiosperms in correct sequence:
(i) Pollen grain lands on stigma (ii) Pollen tube enters the ovule (iii) One sperm fuses with egg (iv) Second sperm fuses with polar nuclei (v) Pollen tube grows through style
options: C) ii  i  v  iv  iii
D) i  v  ii  iv  iii
A) i  v  ii  iii  iv
B) i  ii  v  iii  iv
questions.explanation: The correct sequence is: Pollen grain lands on stigma  Pollen tube grows through the style  Pollen tube enters the ovule through micropyle  One sperm fuses with egg (syngamy)  Second sperm fuses with polar nuclei (triple fusion).

questions.question: Arrange the following in the sequence of decreasing dependence on water for reproduction:
questions.explanation: Algae are aquatic and fully dependent on water. Bryophytes need water for gamete transfer. Pteridophytes need water for movement of flagellated antherozoids. Gymnosperms use pollen tubes and are least dependent on water for fertilization.

questions.question:
Arrange the following in the correct sequence of the life cycle of a fern:
(i) Prothallus (ii) Sporangia on fronds (iii) Spore formation (iv) Young sporophyte (v) Fertilization
options: B) i  ii  iii  v  iv
A) ii  iii  i  v  iv
D) ii  i  iii  iv  v
C) iii  i  v  iv  ii
questions.explanation: In fern life cycle: Mature sporophyte bears sporangia on fronds  Spores formed by meiosis  Spores germinate into prothallus (gametophyte)  Fertilization occurs on the prothallus  Young sporophyte develops.

questions.question:
Arrange the following in the correct sequence of appearance during evolution:
(i) Seeds (ii) Vascular tissue (iii) Flowers (iv) Alternation of generations in land plants
questions.explanation: The evolutionary sequence is: Alternation of generations in early land plants (bryophytes)  Vascular tissue (pteridophytes)  Seeds (gymnosperms)  Flowers (angiosperms).

questions.question:
Arrange the following events during sexual reproduction in bryophytes in correct order:
(i) Antherozoids released (ii) Zygote formed (iii) Sporophyte develops (iv) Spores released (v) Antherozoids swim to archegonium
options: C) i  ii  v  iii  iv
B) v  i  ii  iv  iii
A) i  v  ii  iii  iv
D) iv  i  v  ii  iii
questions.explanation: The correct sequence is: Antherozoids released from antheridia  Swim through water to archegonium  Fertilization produces zygote  Zygote develops into sporophyte  Spores released from capsule of sporophyte.

questions.question: Which of the following gymnosperms has unbranched stems with a crown of large compound leaves?
questions.explanation: Cycas has unbranched stems with a crown of large, pinnately compound leaves at the apex, giving it a palm-like appearance. Pinus has branched stems with needle-like leaves.

questions.question: Zoospores in Chlorophyceae are:
options: B) Flagellated motile asexual reproductive structures
questions.explanation: Zoospores are flagellated, motile asexual reproductive structures produced by many green algae. They are formed inside zoosporangia and help in dispersal and colonization of new habitats.

questions.question:
How many of the following features are common to both gymnosperms and angiosperms?
(i) Presence of seeds (ii) Presence of pollen tubes (iii) Double fertilization (iv) Presence of ovules (v) Vascular tissues present
questions.explanation: Features common to both: (i) seeds, (ii) pollen tubes, (iv) ovules, and (v) vascular tissues. Double fertilization (iii) is unique to angiosperms and is NOT found in gymnosperms.

questions.question:
How many of the following are gymnosperms?
Cycas, Pinus, Ginkgo, Sequoia, Cedrus, Ficus, Gnetum, Ephedra
questions.explanation: Cycas, Pinus, Ginkgo, Sequoia, Cedrus, Gnetum, and Ephedra are all gymnosperms (7 total). Ficus is an angiosperm (flowering plant) and does not belong to gymnosperms.
